p: In City and County of Honolulu v Sunoco oil [119], the claim is that not only have “Native Hawaiian cultural sites, built structures, natural resources, and infrastructure including roads, sewerage, and beach parks, and other resources been more frequently flooded and, in some cases, inundated”, but oil companies knew the climate science, and impending harm to public health since the 1950’s. The state is thus seeking financial compensation for losses, which illustrates how the courts are asked to price the impacts of climate change.
